original: Description: The Hāhārāvatantra (the Tantra of the Roaring Haa, Haa) teaches the worship of Kaula goddesses, especially forms of Kālī, with a very clear preference for Guhyakālī.  Guhyakaalii is one of the most popular form of Kaalii in the Kathmandu Valley, although hardly known outside it. The main Tantra of Guhyakālī is the massive Mahākālasaṃhitā which may well have been redacted in Kathmandu Valley probably after the 14th century. It is likely that the Hāhārāvatantra is also of Nepalese as its preference for Guhyakālī suggests and absence of manuscripts or references to it outside the Valley. Another indication that this so is the presence in the text of the typical Nepalese corruption mahākarmārcana for mahaakramārcana denoting the Kaula liturgy for the worship of Kaula goddesses. This Tantra calls itself an atharvanasaṃhitā and so affiliates itself to the tradition of the Atharva Veda. This is probably because of its extensive treatment of magical rites, incantations and magical potions.
analyzed: description the hāhārāvatantra the tantra of the roaring haa haa teaches the worship of kaula goddesses especially forms of kālī is a veyya clear preference for guhyakālī guhyakaalii is one of the most popular form of kaalii in the kathmandu valley although hardly known outside it the main tantra of guhyakālī is the massive mahākāla saṃhitā which may well have been redacted in kathmandu valley probably after the century it is likely that the hāhārāvatantra is also of nepalese as its prefer

original: The worship of Guhyakālī is the subject of chapters 1, 3, 4 (as śiva), 6 (thousand names of Guhyakālī), 11, and 12, 13, 14. Chapter 2 is dedicated to Pratyaṃgirā, who is another form of Kālī. Chapter 5 contains a long exposition of a mantra called Kālikākavaca . Chapter 7 deals with the worship of goddess Turīyā.
analyzed: the worship of guhyakālī is the subject of chapters  as śiva thousand names of guhyakālī and    chapter is dedicated to pratyaṃgirā who is another form of kālī chapter contains a long exposition of a mantra called kālikākavaca chapter deals with the worship of goddess turīyā

original: Chapter 8 contains a description of the visualized form (dhyāna) of many Kaula goddesses.
analyzed: chapter contains a description of the visualized form dhyāna of many kaula goddesses

original: hapter 9 contains descriptions of Yantras and their worship.
analyzed: contains descriptions of yantras and their worship

original: Chapter  10 deals with magical rites (indrajāla) including magical remedies for disease.
analyzed: chapter deals with magical rites indrajāla including magical remedies for disease

original: Chapter  11 deals with milder magical rites (prayoga) which may also be done for the benefit of others. The texts repeats constantly that these rites, some of which are performed in cremation grounds, should be done without thoughts or doubts (nirvikalpena).
analyzed: chapter deals with milder magical rites prayoga which may also be done for the benefit of others the texts repeats constantly that these rites some of which are performed in cremation grounds should be done without thoughts or doubts nirvikalpena

original: Chapter 15 describes the Kaula worship (kaulikārcana) of Kālī in eight sacrificial vessels.
analyzed: chapter describes the kaula worship kaulika arcana of kālī in eight sacrificial vessels
